newsitem.title: INDIA: Rao's party suspends ex-minister after raids.
newsitem.headline: Rao's party suspends ex-minister after raids.

text.p: India's Congress party has suspended the membership of former communications minister Sukh Ram after police filed a corruption case against him, the United News of India (UNI) said on Wednesday.

The ex-minister's whereabouts remained a mystery on Wednesday, five days after raids on his homes in the capital New Delhi and in the northern state of Himachal Pradesh uncovered more than $1 million in cash.
No formal charges have been laid by the Central Bureau of Investigation (CBI) against the ex-minister, who oversaw an ambitious programme to privatise India's telephone services.

"The Congress president (former Prime Minister P.V. Narasimha Rao) has put Mr Sukh Ram under suspension with immediate effect," UNI quoted Devendra Dwivedi, a close Rao aide, as saying. It did not give further details.
The former minister has denied allegations by opposition political parties that he favoured a little-known firm from his home state, Himachal Pradesh, in the tendering process.
Sukh Ram lost his portfolio when former prime minister P.V. Narasimha Rao's Congress party was defeated in general elections which ended in May.
A senior Department of Telecommunications civil servant has been arrested in the case and police have seized large amounts of cash and jewellery from her home.
Indian officials said help has been sought from the United States to find Sukh Ram, who was abroad for medical treatment during the raids.
Indian newspapers have variously said he is in New York, London or Houston undergoing heart surgery.
